sense.name: Change direction.
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1 [theme[concrete]] BEND NOTE: Always intransitive
sense.examples: The road bends ahead. The Monaco racecourse bends wildly.

sense.name: Bend one's back forward from the waist on down.
sense.examples: The kind gentleman bent to pick up the girl's purse. I bent down to inspect the rock.

sense.name: (Cause to) turn from a straight course, fixed direction, or line of interest; cause to bend or give way.
sense.commentary: NOTE: Entity bent must be abstract. NOTE: Compare to Sense 4; in Sense 3, there is no intent to falsify.
sense.examples: It is unlikely that presidential pleas will lead House Democrats to bend. I will not bend or break. The author bent the story to an unpredictable, incredible conclusion. Furthermore, it is also likely to encourage those on Capitol Hill asking for cuts in the assistance to El Salvador if President Cristiani does not bend to demands of the Marxist guerrillas.

sense.name: Distort or modify with the intent to falsify or make subjective.
sense.commentary: NOTE: Entity bent must be abstract.
sense.examples: Reporters must strive never to bend the truth in order to make a more interesting story. Pressure was put on him to bend the report in a certain direction.

sense.name: Bend a joint.
sense.commentary: NOTE: Body part must be specified.
sense.examples: He painfully bent his elbow for the doctor, revealing the extent of his injury. I bent my knees.

sense.name: Cause to assume a crooked, angular, or twisted form; (cause to) form a curve.
sense.examples: The weightlifter could bend the metal rods without trouble. The stick did not bend. The last time I baked, I tried to bend the dough into a braid.

sense.name: BEND OVER BACKWARD(S): try very hard to please someone.
sense.examples: She bends over backwards when she sees her mother in law. He bent over backward to please her.
